Title: Stay Selling: The Data Shaping Retail Operations For 2024
Text:
CEO of Rallyware.
getty
Ahead of 2024, close observers of the global situation will know to expect the unexpected. From political conflicts to elections, and economic growth to consumer behaviors, there is a great deal up in the air; if the past few years have taught us anything, it is that most predictions of the near future are destined to miss the mark.
In consumer goods sales, we can certainly point to a few practices that will help operations leaders in these verticals stay prepared for the next year.
Yet the most important factor in sales—the customer—is ironically the one that sellers have the least control over. And with retailers posting poor Black Friday results even as consumers feel burdened and frustrated by higher costs, experts at McKinsey are scratching their heads at these mixed signals—questioning both the reason for these consumer behaviors and what behavior might develop next.
Here’s a list of data-based actions that operations leaders can take to prepare for a year that could unfold in countless different ways.
1. Eighty percent of consumers say product knowledge helps provide a positive customer experience.
Retail sales fell in October 2023 (0.1%) for the first time in seven months. While Americans are certainly still purchasing, consumer buying power has decreased with high interest rates and depressed consumer sentiment. Operations leaders should take heed here: In-store sales strategies have to change to accommodate this reality.
One way to counteract decreased purchasing power is increasing customer knowledge so that shoppers feel more comfortable and confident making buying decisions. After all, the advantage of in-person shopping is that the customer can ask store employees for advice and insights, which is particularly helpful for high-ticket items.
In fact, PwC analysts conclude that around 80% of consumers say that "speed, convenience, knowledgeable help and friendly service are the most important elements of a positive customer experience." While consumer goods stores nowadays prioritize speed and convenience, it’s essential not to neglect knowledge.
For 2024, emphasize active employee insight—not only employees who are "more knowledgeable" but employees who are trained and enabled to actively interact with consumers and use their knowledge to compare and contrast potential purchases. This is an efficient way of boosting consumer knowledge without seeming pushy. Plus, it’s likely to drive repeat foot traffic.
2. Extrinsic motivators increase sales volume by two times.
Much has been written about the primacy of intrinsic motivation in seller enablement. Experts have said that the key to achieving retail success is convincing staff to buy into the company’s mission and brand identity. This way, their productivity is not compelled by the company but comes "from within." Trader Joe’s is a great example of this.
Extrinsic motivators—tangible rewards, leaderboards, store recognition—are viewed skeptically in today’s thought leadership on sales. They’re seen as bribes for the sales force and as dated forms of sales operations leadership.
However, data on seller behaviors shows that these motivators are more realistic approximations of what drives and motivates sellers, especially for high-ticket items (think furniture or outdoor goods stores), which have more potential payoff but require more person-to-person persuasion.
According to this report on seller engagement, extrinsic motivators like leaderboards and in-store recognition increased sales volume by two times and boosted retention growth by 81%. Operations leaders should keep this top of mind when planning their frontline rewards and recognition programs for 2024, for instance, by introducing badges and even award ceremonies into store operations and culture.
Store credit is another option. Heather Fencik, Fleet Feet’s education manager, provides a great example in this data-backed business case study: "I just pull a report of who watched the weekly [training] and do a drawing for three five-dollar gift cards, then blast out the winners as an announcement. ... It’s extremely effective."
Psychologically speaking, tangible items and awards give sellers bragging rights both on their résumés and among peers. Gradually, "extrinsic" motivators become intrinsic as sellers develop a concrete stake in their sales numbers. When offering such rewards, operations leaders show that they do care about their sales force, even more than through achieving intrinsic buy-in.
At a time of scarcity and austerity, rhetoric about how "everyone in the store is part of a family" comes cheap. In 2024, leaders will see more mileage from investing in seller success.
3. AI-based sales coaching creates more engaged seller behaviors.
No one would blame sales and operations leaders for having AI fatigue at this point. Yet it’s important to underline exactly how AI can help the sales force and how it cannot. That’s part of developing a clear-eyed digital strategy for 2024.
Using large language models (LLMs), today’s AI chatbots can help sellers in the flow of work. For instance, should a seller need to know technical details about a widescreen TV, she can open a mobile app, ask a company-branded chatbot and get that information on the fly. Particularly at a time when customers are apt to turn to Amazon for their shopping needs, having a sales force with ready access to product knowledge, buying information, install tips and other tidbits will improve customer experience, helping to provide the human touch that online retailers cannot.
Imagine a seller who, when asked a question to which she doesn’t know the answer, says, "Let me look that up for you" instead of running to get a manager. This action instills more confidence in the consumer, and because it requires more seller engagement in the sales process, it has a higher probability of relationship-building.
There’s a reason why data shows that AI-guided sales technology leads to results like over 21% higher sales and three times order size increases: It's because this technology makes the sales interaction better, more engaging and more efficient for both the seller and the consumer.
As Cognizant’s analysts conclude, post-pandemic shoppers want stores to embody a "community vibe." Surprisingly, AI—used correctly—helps stores establish exactly that. Technology at its best makes us more human, not less. Plan for 2024 accordingly.

Title: iPhone Security In The Face Of Zero-Click Exploits
Text:
Apu Pavithran is the founder and CEO of Hexnode, an award-winning unified endpoint management platform.
getty
For Apple enthusiasts and business owners alike, the iPhone has been more than a device—it's a symbol of security and reliability. That doesn't imply, however, that the iPhone is a veritable Fort Knox. Vulnerabilities popping up occasionally are nothing new. However, a recent pair of zero-day vulnerabilities raise considerable concern. In early September 2023, CitizenLab, a vigilant internet watchdog group, unearthed a zero-click iOS vulnerability that enabled the notorious Pegasus spyware to infiltrate iPhones. This revelation serves as a wake-up call, reminding us that even the seemingly impenetrable can be compromised.
Unraveling The Vulnerability
What's truly unsettling is that even the most up-to-date iPhone with the latest iOS can fall victim to this attack without any user interaction. Unlike traditional attacks that require some form of user interaction, this exploit can compromise an iPhone without any action from the victim.
The first exploit, CVE-2023-41064, affects Image I/O, a foundation for programs that enable them to read and write different image formats. A buffer overflow issue in Image I/O may be used to build a maliciously created image that causes iOS to execute malicious software. For those unfamiliar, a buffer overflow takes place when a program tries to input more information into a buffer than it can accommodate. This can lead to various issues such as data distortion, program malfunctions or even the activation of harmful code. The second vulnerability, CVE-2023-41061, affects Apple Wallet and can be exploited to trick it into executing malicious code.
At the end of both vulnerabilities lies Pegasus, a potent and sophisticated spyware developed by Israel's NSO group. Pegasus utilizes the zero-click zero-day vulnerability to inject itself onto iPhones and iPads. Once infiltrated, its capabilities are staggering: It can siphon off texts, emails, media files, contacts and GPS coordinates. Additionally, it can eavesdrop on calls and surreptitiously activate both the microphone and camera.
Marketed under the guise of crime and terrorism prevention, Pegasus has become a favored tool for global governments in surveilling journalists, lawyers, dissidents and activists. In 2021, a consortium of media outlets unearthed alarming evidence: Pegasus had targeted 50,000 individuals across over 50 nations, including politicians and business leaders.
Apple's Rapid Response
Swift and resolute, Apple responded to this revelation by swiftly releasing zero-day patches (iOS 16.6.1) to rectify the vulnerability. This commendable action underscores the company's commitment to user security. However, this incident serves as a strong reminder of the critical role timely software updates play. In today's digital realm, vulnerabilities are swiftly identified and exploited. To stay ahead of potential threats, users must take the initiative to keep their devices up to date.
It's also worth noting that Apple's Lockdown Mode is capable of mitigating the intrusion. Apple's Lockdown Mode allows users to temporarily turn off several of the most frequently used device functionalities, making it far more difficult for malware to access your private phone data. Therefore, enabling this option is highly worthwhile if you're concerned about falling prey to state-sponsored spyware.
Vigilance In An Era Of Uncertainty
But although Apple's prompt action is laudable, it also shines a spotlight on a pressing issue: the millions of devices that remain unpatched. Not every user promptly updates their iOS, and some may be unaware of the urgency posed by these vulnerabilities. This unpatched population represents a ticking time bomb ripe for exploitation. Mitigating this dilemma starts with establishing a robust patch management protocol, which is non-negotiable. This entails consistently overseeing updates, subjecting them to controlled testing environments and ensuring swift deployment. This principle applies not only to operating systems but also to all utilized software and applications.
For enterprises and IT administrators, a comprehensive, unified endpoint management (UEM) strategy helps ensure that all endpoints, including iPhones and iPads, are promptly updated with the latest security patches. It offers a centralized approach to remotely manage devices, safeguarding against potential vulnerabilities.
Finally, users need to be equipped with a comprehensive understanding of the potential hazards they face, along with actionable strategies to fortify their digital defenses. From enabling automatic updates to recognizing suspicious activity, every user plays a crucial role in maintaining the integrity of their digital environment. Moreover, organizations must prioritize cybersecurity awareness and training to create a collective defense against evolving threats.
The revelation of the zero-click iOS vulnerability and the subsequent deployment of Pegasus spyware serve as stark reminders of the evolving threat landscape. In an era in which our existence is ever more entwined with the digital realm, the responsibility rests upon our shoulders to uphold a constant state of watchfulness and foresight. Timely updates coupled with a comprehensive security strategy are our most potent defenses against potential exploits.

Title: The $1.5 Million Effort To Revive Reef Shark Populations
Text:
Silvertip Shark (Carcharhinus albimarginatus) in san Benedicto Island, Revillagigedo. (Photo by: ... [+] Luis Javier Sandoval/VWPics/Universal Images Group via Getty Images) VWPics/Universal Images Group via Getty Images
With global reef shark populations facing a global crisis, Mote Marine Laboratory & Aquarium, in collaboration with international partners, is revamping the Global FinPrint shark survey. This initiative aims to leverage its findings to shape the development of new marine protected areas (also known as MPAs). The Paul G. Allen Family Foundation is generously backing this $1.5 million project, expanding on the initial study as part of a broader mission to restore reef shark populations worldwide.
The inaugural Global FinPrint, conducted from 2015 to 2018 across 58 nations, revealed a global decline in reef sharks, although some MPAs demonstrated resilience in comparison to unprotected areas. Dr. Demian Chapman, the lead scientist for Global FinPrint and Director of the Center for Shark Research Program at Mote Marine Laboratory, suggests that while reef sharks might be dwindling more slowly in MPAs than in unprotected areas globally, this could merely delay their extinction rather than prevent it. “This new phase of Global FinPrint will help us determine which MPAs support healthy, stable reef shark populations, and make sure that nations all over the world set up MPAs that allow reef sharks to recover and thrive for generations to come.”
Shark dive at dive site known a "Tiki", features Gray reef sharks (Carcharhinus amblyrhynchos), ... [+] highlighted by streaks of sunlight. These majestic animals are frequent visitors to the reefs of Moorea. getty
The initial study utilized baited underwater video stations, amassing over 20,000 hours of footage meticulously analyzed for shark sightings. These BRUVs revealed concerning trends, such as functional extinction on nearly 20% of surveyed reefs and a global average decline of 63% across five key reef shark species. These findings informed the recent implementation of international trade regulations for reef sharks under the Convention on International Trade of Endangered Species, or CITES.
Over the next year, Mote, in collaboration with partners across the Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific Oceans, will survey 50 MPAs and 50 control sites previously examined by Global FinPrint throughout 26 nations. The study aims to understand changes and the relationship between MPA design features and reef shark abundance and trends. Factors like size, shape, placement, and shark fishing management outside MPAs will be scrutinized to identify effective strategies for reef shark conservation. The information will be integrated into the Mote Science Education Aquarium’s (Mote SEA) STEM workforce development labs, providing a hands-on learning experience for the next generation of marine scientists. Results will also be shared to influence national MPA planning and fisheries management.
“There is significant opportunity to rigorously assess and understand whether and how MPAs can be designed for effective reef shark conservation,” said Yuta Masuda, director of science of the Paul G. Allen Family Foundation. “This project will also focus on building in-country capacity for reef shark monitoring that will inform local decision-makers on how to achieve conservation commitments.”
Caribbean reef sharks, Carcharhinus perezi, dusk in bahamas. getty
MPAs are designated oceanic zones where human activities, such as fishing or drilling, are regulated or restricted to conserve marine ecosystems and biodiversity; these areas serve as refuges for marine species, promoting their conservation and maintaining the health of marine environments. Many nations are expanding their MPAs as part of a global initiative to protect 30% of oceans by 2030. Further insights into the effectiveness of MPAs will provide valuable data for designing and managing these areas strategically, ensuring they contribute significantly to the broader efforts of preserving reef shark populations and maintaining the ecological balance of marine ecosystems.

Title: Healthcare Interoperability Considerations We Can’t Ignore In 2024
Text:
Sasha Andrieiev is CEO & Co-founder at Jelvix | Digital Leader | Innovation Expert.
getty
With the increasing demand for enhanced patient care, the healthcare sector stands at the crossroads of innovation and challenge. Notably, interoperability is recognized as one of the main principles of how digital health should work.
In 2018, the World Health Assembly (WHA) adopted resolution WHA71.7 on digital health requesting the development of a global strategy for 2020 through 2025. The goal was to improve healthcare delivery by adopting a person-centric approach to digital health solutions.
Healthcare providers wasted no time in responding to the evolving trend. The Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology (ONC) reported that 88% of hospitals used electronic data exchange in 2021 and, compared to 2018, they used more methods to send, receive, store and analyze patient health data. But was the objective of enhancing healthcare with interoperability truly fulfilled?
Why Interoperability Can’t Be Achieved Immediately
As we step into 2024, the journey toward seamless data exchange in healthcare remains challenging. Did you know that almost half of the hospitals (48%) suffer from one-sided data exchange, as reported by the ONC? They share patient data with other providers but don't receive data from them.
The reason is that the path to interoperability is challenging. From navigating varied data formats to addressing cybersecurity, overcoming these challenges helps ensure a future in which healthcare information flows effortlessly for the benefit of patients and the entire healthcare ecosystem.
Standardization Struggles
Achieving interoperability requires a standardized approach to data exchange. However, the diverse landscape of healthcare data formats, from structured electronic health records to unstructured doctor's notes, remains a complex task. The U.S. healthcare system, characterized by its fragmentation, adds complexity as different payers and providers operate on different systems.
It can be a good idea to implement industry-wide standards like Health Level Seven International (HL7) and Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) to create a common language for healthcare data exchange, streamlining interoperability among diverse systems and formats.
Data Quality Dilemma
Addressing the quality of data is crucial in healthcare interoperability. Various types of low-quality information, including irrelevant data, unrepresentative samples, omissions and invalid information, can compromise the accuracy of patient medical records. This challenge spans text, digital, audio and graphic data formats.
To resolve the problem of low-quality text and digits, think about implementing methods of statistical data analysis to identify patterns, outliers and inconsistencies. To enhance the quality of audio and video data, consider applying frequency and spatial filtering techniques. These methods help reduce interference, noise and artifacts, ensuring that healthcare professionals receive clear information. Utilize machine learning algorithms to detect irregularities, imbalances or discrepancies in textual and numerical data.
Security And Privacy Concerns
Increased data sharing in interoperable systems raises the risk of data breaches. The healthcare sector faces significant cybersecurity threats, and interoperability efforts must address these concerns to protect sensitive patient information.
Employing robust encryption methods, implementing electronic document signatures, separating access rights according to the least privilege principle and applying a defense-in-depth strategy can help resolve security-related issues. Also, regular updates of security protocols can ensure compliance with regulations like HIPAA to fortify interoperable systems against cybersecurity threats.
Accessibility Issues
Beyond technical challenges, making health data accessible and understandable to patients for informed consent poses a significant limitation. Bridging the gap between complex medical data and patient comprehension is essential for fostering trust in interoperable healthcare systems.
Developing user-friendly interfaces that comply with the World Wide Web Consortium's (W3C) Web Content Accessibility Guidelines and patient education initiatives may bridge the understanding gap. Providing accessible summaries of complex medical data empowers patients, fostering transparency and trust in interoperable healthcare systems.
How Innovative Tech Can Help
Although challenges persist, innovations such as encryption, AI and cloud-based platforms foster a future healthcare landscape of seamless information flow and improved patient outcomes.
Data Protection Technologies
In the realm of security, technologies such as encryption, secure transfer protocols, immutable data storage and AI-powered threat detection offer robust protection for shared healthcare data. These innovations help ensure that while information flows freely, it remains safeguarded from unauthorized access.
Cloud-Based Solutions
Infrastructure plays a pivotal role in interoperability, and cloud platforms emerge as a key enabler. Platforms like Google Cloud Healthcare API securely ingest, transform and store healthcare data in various formats, including FHIR, HL7v2 and DICOM.
Cloud-based analytics tools process and analyze healthcare data in real time. This enables healthcare providers to access up-to-date information, make informed decisions and enhance patient care.
Digital Consent Platforms
Developing user-friendly digital consent platforms can be a good idea to empower patients to manage access to their health information. Platforms like Apple’s Health Records API foster transparency and empower patients to make informed decisions about their data. ​​Consent management systems help ensure compliance with privacy regulations and allow patients to set preferences, giving them control over how their data is shared and utilized.
Standardization Protocols
Protocols like FHIR are gaining traction within healthcare organizations. FHIR offers a flexible and adaptable standard for the electronic exchange of healthcare data, serving as a unifying language for disparate systems. At the same time, open APIs enable different healthcare applications to communicate and share data, promoting interoperability across diverse systems.
Looking Ahead: Collective Action For Interoperability
Although the horizon of interoperability in healthcare looks promising, it requires collective action to shape a connected future. Healthcare providers play a central role, aligning their practices with interoperability standards to facilitate seamless data exchange and enhanced patient care. Patients contribute by actively participating in their healthcare journey, embracing digital tools and advocating for transparent data sharing.
Technology developers can drive innovation, creating interoperable solutions that bridge existing gaps in healthcare systems. Regulatory bodies can establish and enforce standards that guide interoperability practices, helping ensure data security and privacy.
Final Words
As we stand on the cusp of 2024, the future of interoperability in healthcare holds the promise of a more connected, efficient and patient-centric healthcare system. As technological innovations continue to unfold and collaborative efforts intensify, we can expect a transformative impact on how healthcare information is shared and accessed. The road ahead may be complex, but the destination promises a revolutionized approach to patient care.

Title: Why Is TikTok Parent ByteDance Moving Into Science and Drug Discovery?
Text:
TikTok’s Chinese parent is beginning to recruit across the U.S. for experts in science and healthcare disciplines far afield from social media. Its motives are unclear.
By Alexandra S. Levine , Forbes Staff
B yteDance, the Chinese parent company of TikTok, appears to be ramping up work in fields well beyond the bounds of social media: Biology, chemistry, natural sciences and pharmaceuticals.
The Beijing-based tech giant is recruiting American talent in computational biology, quantum chemistry, molecular dynamics and physics for its “AI for Drug Design” and “AI for Science” teams, according to LinkedIn posts reviewed by Forbes. ByteDance appears to be hiring for at least 17 of these positions across New York, California and Washington state—taking a swing at local rivals like Meta, Google and Amazon, where similar work is already underway. (Others leading these efforts at ByteDance appear to be based in Chicago, Boston and Beijing, according to LinkedIn.)
The AI for Drug Design team aims to “revolutionize drug discovery,” says one job listing recruiting PhD students to Silicon Valley. “We are dedicated to pushing the boundaries of AI-driven drug design, tackling complex challenges in protein structure prediction, molecular conformation analysis, and computational protein design. By combining our passion for scientific excellence with the transformative power of AI, we aim to accelerate drug discovery and make a meaningful impact on global healthcare.”
ByteDance’s AI for Science group, meanwhile, “has been focusing on tackling challenges in natural sciences, including biology, physics, and materials,” say listings for research scientists in computational biology and quantum chemistry in Seattle. And those interning in molecular dynamics in New York will be responsible for pursuing “novel strategies for computer-aided drug discovery” and advancing “free energy methodologies.”
Staffers across the board will “co-create a future” with ByteDance, the listings say.
What, exactly, that future is to be isn’t clear. It is also unclear how drug discovery or development, and other science-focused efforts, fit into ByteDance’s sprawling repertoire of social media sensations like TikTok and its Chinese counterpart Douyin. ByteDance declined to comment on what its objectives are, how large the AI for Drug Design and Science teams are today and who it may have already hired. But a head of AI for drug design and science started at the company this past summer, per LinkedIn—an expert who is also running UCLA’s General Artificial Intelligence Lab—and the team has already released research on protein design and drug design, and an open-source tool combining structural biology with AI.
TikTok did not respond to requests for comment.
How TikTok could help
Forbes found no indication that these ByteDance initiatives are related to TikTok, and TikTok did not respond to a request for comment about whether they are in any way linked.
But experts said data from TikTok and other platforms owned by ByteDance could be highly valuable for these science initiatives. (And though TikTok has emphasized that it operates largely separately from its Chinese parent, Forbes reporting has repeatedly revealed the extent to which the businesses are entangled and data from one company is often accessible by both.)
"They could be doing large-scale hypothesis generation with all this data, and then they could be feeding that data into Chinese pharmaceutical companies or Chinese weapons manufacturers.” Eric Perakslis, former chief scientist for informatics at the FDA
In the development of new drugs or medical treatments, experts and pharmaceutical companies typically work around what’s called a “target product profile,” a rubric that helps them distill what their optimal drug would look like, the conditions or key problems they’d address with it and who their ideal patients, candidates or markets are. Experts said TikTok—where many people are drawn to health and wellness content, talk openly about medical issues, and regularly seek information on what has (or hasn’t) worked for others—could serve as an invaluable feedback loop and marketing tool for drug developers. Spending data collected from TikTok Shop and in-app purchases could also be useful.
"Based on the kinds of videos that [young TikTok users] watch or the content that they consume, it might provide insights as to conditions that they're facing,” said Douglas Schmidt, associate provost for research and co-director of the Data Science Institute at Vanderbilt University, who noted that many young Americans are medicated for ADHD, anxiety and other mental health conditions. “If you could find a way to sell products that would be appealing to them, you can certainly imagine [building] up a robust pharmaceuticals industry or a competitive product, then advertising it on TikTok.”
Eric Perakslis, a former chief scientist for the FDA who previously helped lead pharmaceuticals R&D for Johnson & Johnson, called this “surveillance capitalism basics: everything that you can extract from those things, they do.”
“Given that they're a social media company, and given that they don't have life science divisions that are consenting patients, taking samples or running mice and rat studies and stuff like that—their own data—I think it's a fair assumption that somehow they're accessing data” from elsewhere, said Perakslis.
This growing arm of ByteDance could be a “very big, large antenna,” he added—a way of pulling in a “big noisy mess of data,” filtering it through experts and then figuring out how to monetize it.
"They could be doing large-scale hypothesis generation with all this data, and then they could be feeding that data into Chinese pharmaceutical companies or Chinese weapons manufacturers or Chinese whatever,” Perakslis said. (ByteDance’s head of research appears to be based in Beijing, per LinkedIn.) Beyond drug discovery or repurposing, he noted the language used in these roles could also portend work in food science, agrochemical, petroleum, fuels science or even bioweapons. “The same technologies that allow us to develop new medicines can be used for bioweapons,” Perakslis said. “It's a very similar set of capabilities.”
Finally, experts said the roles signal that TikTok’s owner is looking to channel its AI prowess—embodied best by the unmatched TikTok algorithm that steers its ultra-personalized “For You” feed—into other revenue streams. That hypothesis jibes with the job descriptions: Those joining ByteDance’s “multidisciplinary drug discovery team” will be tasked with “applying inventive algorithms” to its work and developing algorithms for antibody design. Other hires will build “cutting-edge machine learning technologies in scientific areas like biology, physics and materials.”
State of play
This is not the first time that ByteDance—which established the ByteDance AI Lab in 2016—has ventured into industries that seemingly have little to do with TikTok, Douyin and social media more broadly.
Healthcare is just one of many. Last year, ByteDance bought Chinese hospital chain Amcare for $1.5 billion—a push to establish a foothold in the space after ByteDance had acquired online medical encyclopedia Baikemy in 2020 and subsequently launched a suite of healthcare apps under the name Xiaohe. Experts at the time told Forbes those moves reflected the Chinese government’s mandate for the country to be a global leader in health by the end of this decade.
What’s different now, though, is that ByteDance appears to be expanding those efforts beyond China into the United States—hiring scientists and PhDs in at least three major U.S. cities. And in doing so, it’s planting a flag in a market where some of its biggest American competitors have their own science, research or health-focused initiatives underway and edging into their AI research talent pool.
“They've attracted a lot of negative publicity about TikTok. … Maybe they're trying to diversify into fields that are viewed more positively by governments and regulators.” Douglas Schmidt, co-director of the Data Science Institute at Vanderbilt
Like ByteDance, these U.S. rivals are tech behemoths that are trying to win in industries well outside their bread-and-butter businesses. Google parent Alphabet is pursuing breakthroughs in tech and science through its Moonshot Factory (previously called Google X). Google DeepMind, the search giant’s innovation lab for AI and neuroscience, recently released a model that can mimic human reasoning. Meta AI, a research hub from the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, is transforming medicine by deploying AI to improve and expand access to MRIs and help doctors read and make predictions off X-rays. And Amazon has had its own foray into healthcare, acquiring OneMedical in 2022. (TikTok Shop, which the platform launched in the U.S. in September, is also a growing threat for Amazon.)
“They're undoubtedly trying to find a way to leapfrog or get access to people with skills in those areas,” said Schmidt, the professor from Vanderbilt.
Got a tip about ByteDance or TikTok? Reach out securely to Alexandra S. Levine on Signal/WhatsApp at (310) 526–1242, or email her at alevine@forbes.com.
But ByteDance’s segue into the sciences could also simply be a way for the Chinese company to improve its goodwill in the U.S. as talks of a TikTok ban loom and the app faces heavy scrutiny for its effect on the American public and discourse, he added.
“They've attracted a lot of negative publicity about TikTok and its corruption on the youth of America,” Schmidt said. “But when we start thinking about healthcare and science, that comes across as more corporately responsible and trying to help for the good of humanity. … Maybe they're trying to diversify into fields that are viewed more positively by governments and regulators.”
After all, as ByteDance says itself: “Our goal is to create breakthroughs in natural science with new methodology and help the world.”

Title: The Fight For Longevity: How Companies Can Innovate And Evolve
Text:
Executive Vice President and Chief Technology Officer at Motorola Solutions.
getty
More than 2,200 companies have been featured on the Fortune 500 list since its inception in 1955. A small fraction of this group—49 companies to be exact—have been featured on this list consecutively for the past 68 years. For companies and investors alike, longevity is the elusive yet highly sought-after prize.
The world changes, markets change, technology changes—and companies must innovate and evolve to thrive in the long term. As chief technology officer at a 95-year-old technology company and as a founder of startups, I’ve seen firsthand the grit and adaptability that is required to overcome corporate mortality. In an age where the average company lifespan is just shy of 20 years, here are three ways companies can foster innovation and breathe new life into their corporate coding for an enduring legacy.
Learn fast instead of failing fast.
The mantra “Fail fast” is commonly touted throughout the tech industry. Innovation often requires venturing into the unknown. You are exploring paths to a solution and you might encounter dead-ends along the way. Mapping and learning from every explored path is critical to the process of innovation. Failure is never the goal and true failure is not learning from every change in direction. An agile organization can learn fast and every mistake makes it better.
Practice resilience over redundancy. The quote from an old song, “If at first, you don’t succeed, try, try again,” is catchy and well-intentioned, but innovation is not a random occurrence or consequence of good luck. As an intern at the National Cancer Institute, I quickly learned that I wasn’t good at lab work. Concepts from immunology, however, inspired me to explore computational biology and artificial intelligence. One doctorate in machine learning later, I created two video security startups that were bought by Fortune 500 companies. From my experience, resilience is more consistent with John Wooden’s quote, “Failure isn’t fatal, but failure to change might be.”
Take pride in the solution, not the invention.
Identify areas for growth and fill those gaps accordingly. Startups sprout to fill market needs through hyper-focused innovation—and strategic acquisitions can buoy both companies, large and small, producing stronger corporate DNA and solidifying the foundation for long-term survival. Aside from adding new products or intellectual property to the company’s portfolio, such acquisitions yield something much more valuable: fresh perspectives from its employees.
Leaders of the acquiring company must be open-minded and demonstrate to new employees that they appreciate their incoming value. It’s important to send the message that they’re acquiring the startup because it does something the larger company cannot achieve—which means the acquiring company will have to change. At the same time, the company being acquired must also be open to whatever changes the new setup brings. The new organization will be unique and better, with neither unit being what it was before—which is the goal.
Support a culture of collaboration.
No one person has a monopoly on good ideas. Collaboration fosters creativity which, in turn, fuels innovation. To promote more meaningful collaboration, I encourage my teams to dedicate a consistent fraction (such as 10%) of their time towards their passion projects. The primary goal is to create a rich funnel of ideas and an environment where the best ideas get to flourish.
Importantly, companies must remember that people are their most valuable asset. High-performing teams are built on a foundation of trust and open communication, where every individual is empowered to raise their hand, share new ideas and offer feedback. The foundational question for constructive debate should always be: “How can we make this work?” rather than “Here are the reasons why it won’t work.” This layer of psychological safety is invaluable in ensuring the success of the team and must be implemented at every level of the organization.
In a society obsessed with the freshness of youth, companies with fresh ideas are often overlooked. Yet these companies, permanent fixtures on the Fortune 500 list, are the ones that have left an indelible impact on daily life. From the way we think, move and communicate, these titans capable of radical transformation have shaped the course of history. For companies seeking similar long-term success, know that innovation is a never-ending pursuit rather than a destination—and the journey is worth it.

Title: The Coming AI Code Generation Chaos May Already Be Here: Solutions?
Text:
Andrii Korolov is the Founder of Maven Group and an AI-powered DevEx platform Transformatic.
getty
In addition to solving many problems around fast, easy and accurate software code generation, AI will help create much more new code. That will create problems for everyone managing it. But, those problems don’t have to cause chaos. The good news is that companies that have successfully managed to tame code management chaos and gain a degree of control, standardization and predictability may have an answer for the coming explosion of AI-generated code.
Picture a company with zero software engineers in 2000 that now boasts over 10,000 software developers. Their work supports millions of useful self-service actions initiated by their customers, like browsing product details or requesting a credit line increase at an online bank. The company's software teams make 10,000 software product code updates daily, use all kinds of services and software tools while trying to balance their performance and usage costs, and train hundreds of machine learning models in real time.
Enterprises whose software-related challenges look like that are becoming increasingly common. For companies whose business processes run on code, growing efficiently without descending into complete management chaos should be a challenge on their Top 10 list.
To solve the code management problem associated with rapidly expanding tools, practices and standards, it helps to understand how the problem grows.
Small companies typically give considerable freedom to their software teams, who usually end up building monoliths, or unified software applications that are self-contained and independent from other applications. But this freedom has a cost. Program managers often have no way of knowing whether developers apply product updates correctly, or whether they use the best coding practices. As a result, code errors and security vulnerabilities grow—and so do timelines for finding bugs and fixing errors.
To regain control, midsize companies often migrate to break down software monoliths into smaller, better-manageable software ecosystems called microservices. Switching to a microservices architecture also allows them to benefit from cloud efficiencies.
But even having reached the ideal size of microservices, with component conflicts reduced and a good time to market achieved, other problems surface: With many different technologies in the mix, the cognitive load for software developers increases and becomes a barrier.
What is cognitive load? It’s the skill level of an individual software developer needed to make and run an application. More microservice components mean more cognitive load, so the development speed slows down, and costs increase. In addition, the proliferation of microservices complicates governance, compliance and security.
Now, larger companies are looking to cut development costs, implement optimization algorithms, gain control of microservices governance and improve and automate security with compliance built in. Their leaders look into building internal platforms that standardize and streamline the processes that manage workflows, code, pipelines, infrastructure and data.
Possible solutions combine standardization of routine tasks, a curated number of tools that work in concert and an environment where roles regulate access levels, permissions and resource access levels—and doing it all with transparency and visibility for the management.
Internal developer platforms (IDPs) are one such solution that attempts to combine those features. Implementing platforms allows management to push centralized decisions across all teams and help remove biased decisions by teams who have been used to using various tools of their choice chaotically, so a switch to platform thinking also requires a culture shift that not every developer may love.
How can businesses that choose the platform approach improve the chances of adopting it successfully?
• Start With The Build Vs. Buy Evaluation: Although engineers prefer to build something from scratch, a more practical approach that can deliver results faster may be to customize one of the existing platforms available on the market. Start with customizable open platforms. If it needs too much customization, you can consider a more specialized platform to fit your industry and your specific IT environment.
• Go For Easy Wins: The chances are that many development teams have a nagging issue they've been struggling with that a platform may be able to help address. For example, tasks that prevent developers from doing work with business impact—like the wait between requesting a new project environment and getting it or having to choose, support and monitor another development tool all on their own.
• Define And Communicate Platform Scope: For example, the best candidates for standardizing the majority of development environments are monitoring, logging, debugging, security, authentication and authorization, connections to back-end systems, failover, load shedding and throttling, common shared libraries, testing infrastructure, and release infrastructure—but you don't have to implement them all at once. But, do communicate the rules that will still allow developers to choose their own tools outside of the platform.
• Be Ready To Offer Help: Groom or hire outside experts who will be available to train and will be available to answer questions the developers may have.
Implementing an IDP and encouraging platform thinking is a challenge that takes time. Today, the main reason for an approach favoring automation and standardization is the need for companies to keep the marginal cost of developing new products low, and the speed of new product releases fast.
Soon, as codebases swell, even smaller teams may start facing code and tool management problems that larger companies face now. AI code generation tools are already here. Some are already integrated into developer tools, like OpenAI's Codex and GitHub’s Copilot. Other developers are testing the possibilities with ChatGPT.
What’s already clear is that the volume of code is already set to rise exponentially. My concern is that many companies will not be ready, so they cannot take full advantage of the new possibilities. A shift in thinking that prioritizes keeping the cognitive load manageable offers a promising solution in a world with a lot more code.
